title: Can you be banned, chat restricted exc. for being reported unjustly?
body: Example- Being reported by the same guys when you are matched with them multiple times in a row and reported each time for verbal abuse, getting the box notifying you that you have been reported even if you have not said a thing to them.    Was just curious.

replies.body: False reports will be disregarded by the system, and if that player abuses the report system the reports will lose value. If you did nothing wrong you can ignore those messages.
Thank you

To build upon what Look is saying; don't think of a report as the end all be all when it comes to determining a punishment.  They help our systems record patterns and look closely at specific games.  

We're at a really cool point in League where our systems have a certain level of awareness.  If toxic behavior is not detected, then no disciplinary action will be taken.  Even if you received 9 reports in a game, you wouldn't have to worry as long as your behavior wasn't toxic in any way.

The more reports a person makes for silly things the less "value" the system will place in their report, eventually ignoring it all together.

> [{quoted}](name=WookieeCookie,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=Lw9YEa9O,comment-id=000000000000,timestamp=2015-11-05T06:05:13.290+0000)

Skynet was created by LOL to punish flamers?  EVERYBODY RUN!!!



> The more reports a person makes for silly things the less "value" the system will place in their report, eventually ignoring it all together.

This is something that scares me.  I get why you do it, but on the other hand, if I'm having a streak where someone on either side is being toxic enough that I think it is worth looking at, I'm worrying if the system is starting ignore me because I'm on a bad streak when it comes to people in my games.  Let's say you've got a 1 in 10 chance of having a toxic person in a game. Sure that translates to 1 in 10,000 for having 4 in a row, but there's 8 million LOL players or whatever.   Hypothetically you should be getting that occur 800 times everyone of those 8 million people play 4 games.

So let's say whoever is right on his reports half of the time and the other half are borderline stuff riot lets slip.  That's still 2 silly reports for 800 people.  If anything, this makes me a little hesitant to report something that I think is questionable because I dunno how the system thinks of my reporting.  

I'm not getting any feedback on them.  Ever.  No good job for a 90% reporting accuracy.  No bad job if I only hit 10% of them.  

So if I run into someone who's AFK but isn't red postgame, that's one of those things I worry about reporting.

Your concerns make sense to me.  It's hard for me to answer because we don't want to provide specifics about how reporting works.  Doing so opens up the opportunity for less honorable players to try and game the system.

What I would say is that what you described is something that's on our minds when thinking about reports and how they work.  Similar to how our systems for bad behavior are based off of patterns rather than just single incidents, our view of reports is the same.  The goal isn't to punish players who may report behavior they consider bad (even if that behavior is in the grey area), but instead to get those who use the report system as a retaliatory tool against those who are playing the game legitimately.

Well, I'm glad you guys are thinking about this at least. 

So as long as I'm not using reports as retaliation, I should be fine more or less?

Question about the reverse end of Linna's question.
Given a player who is has semi-consistent negative behavior, is falsely reported and then a punishment case is made.  The person who falsely reports would have their report weight increased would they not?

Also how does the automated system handle false reports?  I've seen recent reform cards with relatively tame games listed on them, which means the false report was used to build the case and not discarded.

I for instance report a lot of players, cause I think that even if they are not "toxic" in the way they don't insult or harass, i still think that calling out the entire team (noob, NOOOB, NOOOOOBSSS) 5 times in the game isn't fostering a positive attitude. By how quick people leave the end game lobby, i'm pretty sure that most people don't bother reporting those kind of people (maybe they don't care, maybe they think it's a waste of time). I would be happy to tune it down (or up) and adjust the treshold of what should be reported or not if I had any kind of feedback concerning how valuable the system thinks my input is

I think there should be some sort of indication that your reports are losing weight (or are now worthless). Could help show people that their reports are worth something, and if they aren't, show them that they need to stop reporting frivolously.

Hypothetically, it's possible. Any false positive case (wherein an innocent player is punished) must inherently have involved false reports. *However*, it's very rare - somewhere less than 1 case in 6000 (or ~0.01667% of cases).

As such, I don't think it's worth worrying about.

EDIT: Corrected a rounding error I inadvertently left in.

EDIT2: Apparently math is hard - I massively screwed up my calculations. But it's fixed now. Apologies for any confusion.

Well, I started with Lyte's [quoted error rate](https://www.reddit.com/r/leagueoflegends/comments/38g6ns/riot_lyte_are_you_aware_of_how_support_operates/cruylpx) from their spot checks of the system (posted 5 months ago):

> currently hovering around 1 error in every 5000 cases to 6000 cases

Then I did math to find the upper bound of possible false positives (1 divided by 6000 = 1.66666667 x 10^-4 or 0.0001667, then multiply by 100 to get percentage = 0.001667%). I rounded strangely, because I'm strange. Actually, it's because I had originally intended to indicate that the 6 seems to repeat, but then decided not to, but didn't fix the rounding error that left.

If you have a correction to my math, feel free to post it. If you have concerns with Lyte's numbers, perhaps take that up with someone who might know something about it. I'm just sharing relatively-inaccessible information. Nothing more, nothing less.

On the one hand? I agree with you - having a solid understanding of what is and isn't acceptable is pretty important.

On the other hand, though, I think this is one of those cases where it may be *overall* better for it to remain under-defined. There's outlier cases (like yours) where stricter definitions would serve well, but there's also cases where strict definitions allow for manipulable loopholes.

In the long run, I'm not sure which is the better option, but I trust that Riot is at least *trying* to make the best decision they can given the data they have.

That's **extremely** arbitrary - it's impossible to see a fraction of an error due to the binary nature of the thing, so they'd either see a 0% error rate, or a 0.001% (1 in 1,000) error rate.

I strongly believe that the Reform Cards should focus on showing the games that are most strongly indicative of the behavior that led to the player's punishment, rather than simply the most recent reported games.

> The standard is vague, the statistic is vague, Riot likes to be vague about everything.

EDIT: I decided that I wanted to look at the difference between the two samples you put forth in your first paragraph. Specifically:

> I mean say they reviewed 12,000 (random number to work with the 1:6000 ratio) and found 2 false positives, but if they reviewed the next 6000 and found 5+ more false positives.

I'm doing this math on an actual spreadsheet, rather than my own head. As I'll show, I screwed up my earlier math, so I'll go back and edit that post to correct the screw-up.

In the first case, we see 2 errors out of 12,000 cases - an error rate of 0.01667%. Which means an accuracy of 99.98333%

In the second chunk, we see 5 errors out of 6,000 cases - an error rate of 0.08333%. This gives an accuracy of 99.91667%

Combining the two, we see 7 errors out of 18,000 cases - an error rate of 0.03889%. This gives an accuracy of 99.96111%.

I'm not drawing any conclusions from this, because it came from a hypothetical. I was just curious about what kind of impact that might actually have, statistically.

I trust Riot to do their work correctly and do solely blame the 'possible variance' in any margin of error.

Given that the false positive rate was based on an absolutely clean case, i can accept the 1:6000 ratio.
